EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - PHILLIPS 66 COMPANY - FREEPORT TERMINAL MIDSTREAM
FIRST TIME SUBMISSION

I.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Phillips 66 Company has a long standing commitment to the environment and to employee and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training, written procedures, routine maintenance and inspection programs, and consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous chemicals. However, if a release should occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

II.	DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Freeport LPG Export Terminal Midstream project is designed to export LPG- Export Grade Propane (EGP) and N-Butane- and C5+ from the Freeport Terminal. 

Export Grade Propane (EGP) is received from either the Sweeny NGL Fractionation 1 facility located at the Sweeny Refinery or the Clemens -Midstream terminal. The EGP is chilled, stored at atmospheric pressure and loaded onto ships for export. N-Butane is received from the Sweeny NGL Fractionation 1 facility or the Clemens terminal. The normal-butane is chilled, and loaded onto ships for export. The LPG loading facility is expected to accommodate 8-10 VLGC cargos per month. The LPG Refrigeration process utilizes the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant, offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics:  There are no RMP covered Toxics over the threshold quantity for this process.

Flammables:  Ethane, Propane, Propylene, Iso-Butane, N-Butane; Carbon Oxysulfide, Ethyl Mercaptan.
 

The C5+ product is received directly from the Sweeny NGL Fractionation 1, 2, and 3 facilities, stored and loaded onto ships for export. The C5+ system

is designed to receive 40,000 bbl/day of C5+ product on a continuous basis and to load parcels as large as 300,000 bbl onto tankers at a rate of 15,000 bbl/hr from still tanks.  The C5+ Storage & Loading process utilizes the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant, offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics:  There are no RMP covered Toxics over the threshold quantity for this process.

Flammables:  Butane; isoPentane; Pentane.

III.	HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS

At the heart of the Risk Management Plan rule is the requirement to conduct a hazard assessment to examine and communicate potential offsite impacts of releases of regulated hazardous substances. Two types of releases are to be considered, a Worst Case Scenario and an Alternate Release Scenario. The WCS (representing a catastrophic event) is defined as a release with the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint. The ARS represents a more credible, but still potentially significant, accidental release of a regulated hazardous material. It is also understood that active and passive mitigation systems can be considered in developing the ARS. However, in some cases mitigation measures and systems may not have been included to its fullest extent in order to create potential worst-case alternate release scenarios. In helping to establish the Alternate Release Scenarios that are more credible and likely, certain information such as previous incident history, PHA failure scenarios, siting and spacing studies, etc. were considered.

Note: For Security purposes, the Offsite Consequence Analysis description and scenarios are not shown in the Executive Summary.

IV.	GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

The following is a summary of the general Accident Prevention Program in place for the Freeport Termin

al C5+ Storage & Loading facility. Because processes at the plant are subject to both EPA Risk Management Program Rule and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) compliance, this summary addresses each of the PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the Accident Prevention Program.

A. Employee Participation

Facility management supports and encourages employees to participate in all facets of risk management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to information created as part of the facility's Accident Prevention Program. In addition, a number of initiatives that address process safety and employee safety issues are utilized and involve forming problem-solving teams to promote both process safety and employee safety:

Personnel representing operations, maintenance, support, and management work together on Area Safety Teams to represent facility employees involving the following areas:
Employee Ownership and VPP
Pollution Prevention
Area Safety Inspection and Auditing
Process Safety/PSM

B. Process Safety Information

The Freeport Terminal facility maintains a variety of technical documents that are used for the safe and reliable operation of facility processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific teams/groups within the facility are assigned responsibility for maintaining current and up-to-date process safety information. Process safety information documents are readily available for review and use (e.g. during unit process hazard analysis, etc.). The facility Management of Change (MOC) process is utilized to maintain process safety information current and up-to-date.

Ch

emical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). For specific process areas, the complex has documented safety related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, and composition) in the unit specific Process Safety Information (PSI). The respective teams verify the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel and instrumented protective systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems, etc.).

Numerous technical documents are also maintained that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to confirm that safety features in the process are not compromised.

C. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

A formal PHA process is established to help ensure that potential process-related hazards are identified and controlled. PHAs are conducted to systematically examine covered processes to identify potential process-related hazards and verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The HAZard and OPerability (HAZOP) analysis technique is the primary method used to perform these PHA evaluations. Additional PHA tools and methodologies (e.g., Layers of Protection Analysis, What-If, etc.) are utilized based on need and appropriateness for the process under review. The PHAs are conducted using a team of people who have operating, maintenance and process engineering experience and expertise.

Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking as

signed by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive appropriate priority attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked to completion. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained in the facility formal corrective action tracking database.

To confirm the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Freeport Terminal facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer in operation.

D. Operating Procedures

Written operating procedures that address the various modes of process operations, to include unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process have been developed. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Formal processes and procedures are developed and maintained through the Training Team to help ensure operating procedures are periodically reviewed and certified annually as current and up-to-date.

E. Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, a comprehensive training program is maintained consisting of various job/certification models for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in plant operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration, etc.) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks

in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to confirm their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

F. Contractors

The Freeport Terminal facility uses contractors as part of its regular work force and during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to help verify contractors have the appropriate knowledge and skills to perform their work in a safe manner, are aware of the potential hazards in their workplace, understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, understand and follow site safety rules and procedures, and inform plant personnel of any hazards they may discover during the course of their work. Information is communicated and provided to contractors to help accomplish this to include:
Process overviews,
Information regarding safety and health hazards (e.g., SDSs),
Emergency Response Plan information,
Safe work practices applicable to contractor work activities.

In addition, contractor safety programs and performance is evaluated as part of the contractor selection process. Plant personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to help ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. Meetings are held monthly with facility contractors and plant personnel to promote effective information sharing and to ensure site and work requirements are adequately communicated.

G. Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)

As required by the OSHA PSM standard and in accordance with the EPA RMP Accident Prevention Program requirements, the Freeport Terminal facility conducts PSSRs for any new facility or when existing facilities/processes are modified and requires

a change in the process safety information. The intent of the PSSR is to confirm various features are in place prior to placing the equipment in service, such as: proper hazard reviews, procedures, personnel training, and that equipment is constructed and installed per design. The PSSR review team uses checklist-type questions to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that Accident Prevention Program requirements are properly implemented. The PSSR process is an integral part of the overall facility Management of Change / Pre-Startup Safety Review process. As indicated below under the Management of Change element, an MOC Subcommittee has been established and meets on a routine basis to monitor the facility MOC/PSSR process, conduct training and education on the process, conduct audits of completed MOCs, and to update the MOC/PSSR program and procedure as needed.

H. Mechanical Integrity

Procedures and practices are established to help ensure covered process equipment is maintained in a safe and reliable condition, to include: pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems. The basic aspects of this program include: training, written procedures, inspections and tests, correcting identified deficiencies, and applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on an overview of the process, safety and health hazards, applicable maintenance procedures, emergency response plans, and the applicable safe work practices necessary to perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures confirm work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to verify equipment functions as intended, an

d to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back in service (if possible), or appropriate personnel/teams will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to verify the continued safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program is quality assurance. Quality assurance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs to help ensure new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

I. Safe Work Practices

The Freeport Terminal facility has well established written safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include: control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, lockout/tagout procedures to verify proper isolation of energy sources for equipment maintenance, procedures for the safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, hot work permit procedures, confined space entry procedures, and safety and emergency systems bypass permit/procedure. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

J. Management of Change

Written procedures are developed to manage changes to covered processes. These procedures require that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and changes to facilities that may affect a covered process, are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Hazard reviews are conducted to verify adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical ha

zard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated as necessary to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change. An MOC Subcommittee meets quarterly to monitor the facility MOC/PSSR process, and to conduct audits of completed MOCs.

K. Incident Investigation

The Freeport Terminal facility utilizes a well-established, formal incident reporting and investigation process to promptly investigate all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, chemical release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops corrective actions to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to plant management and respective Teams for resolution. Corrective actions documented in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked to completion in the facility formal incident reporting and corrective action tracking database, and retained in accordance with the company document records retention policy.

L. Compliance Audits.

To confirm the Accident Prevention Program is functioning properly, the Freeport Terminal facility periodically conducts audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the Accident Prevention Program are being implemented. Formal compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years. These formal audits are conducted and documented as part of the Corporate Audit process. In addition, periodic internal self-audits are conducted to verify compliance on an on-going basis. A report of any findings from the compliance audits are documented in the facility formal corrective action tracking database a

nd tracked to completion. The two most recent audit reports are retained for review.

M. Freeport Terminal Facility HSE Management System

The Freeport Terminal facility utilizes and implements a corporate a Health, Safety & Environmental Management process to:
Demonstrate management commitment to HSE,
Ensure all reasonably practical steps are taken to identify the hazards/risks arising from the facility's business activities,
Systematically integrate HSE activities into new and existing business processes,
Ensure regulatory compliance,
Promote high standards and continuous improvement of HSE excellence.

The HSE Management System promotes involvement of facility employees, and is comprised of various HSE elements. On an annual basis, these elements are evaluated with facility employees to assess the status and implementation plans of each element, and additional action plans or enhancements are developed for continued HSE performance. The elements consisting of the HSE Management System include:

Policy and Leadership 
Risk Assessment
Legal Requirements and Standards of Operation
Strategic Planning, Goals and Objectives
Structure and Responsibility
Programs and Procedures
Asset and Operation Integrity 
Emergency Preparedness
Awareness, Training and Competency
Non-Conformance, Investigation and Corrective Action
Communication
Document Control and Records Management
Measurement and Monitoring
Audits
Review

These elements, combined with the OSHA PSM elements, help ensure a comprehensive Accident Prevention Program.

N. Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at the Freeport Terminal facility involve potential hazards that must be managed to help ensure continued safe operation. The Accident Prevention Program summarized previously is applied to all EPA RMP covered process at the plant. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and hu

man errors.

In addition to the Accident Prevention Program activities, there are safety features on many processes to help quickly detect a release, contain/control a release, and reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection:
Gas Detectors (Hydrocarbon, H2S, etc.) with alarms
Camera surveillance
Routine unit operator rounds/inspections of equipment

Release Containment/Control:
Process relief valves that discharge to a flare system to capture and incinerate episodic releases
Block valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automatic)
Automated Shutdown Systems for specific process parameters (e.g., level, flow, temperature, etc.)
Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump)
Diked areas
Check valves
Flare systems
Structural/equipment fire proofing

Release Mitigation:
Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
Deluge systems for specific equipment
Trained emergency response personnel
Personal Protective Equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
Emergency Isolation Valves
Emergency Activation Systems
Rapid Notify Community Alert Network
Risk Based Inspection

V.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no RMP events with offsite impacts, or incidents involving covered regulated substances that met RMP reporting criteria.  

As indicated above under the Incident Investigation element, the Freeport Terminal facility has a formal written incident investigation process that is designed to identify root causes of incidents and develop appropriate corrective actions to prevent recurrence. Risk assessments are also made of incidents. However, the Freeport Terminal facility's focus and philosophy is in the area of preventing accidents, and controls and measures are developed and implemented to help accomplish this.

VI.	EME

RGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Freeport Terminal facility maintains written Emergency Response Procedures and Action Plans to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, procedures that are utilized address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The Emergency Response Program is periodically reviewed and updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other plant facilities.

The overall Emergency Response Program is coordinated with the Brazoria County Emergency Planning Committee (BCEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. The Freeport Terminal facility has around the clock communications capability with appropriate BCEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire departments). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. Periodic emergency drills are conducted that involve the BCEPC and local emergency response organizations. In addition to the BCEPC, the Freeport Terminal facility also has a Mutual Aid System in place, the Emerg

ency Assistance Agreement Committee (EAAC) which is a subcommittee of the Industrial CAER organization in the Brazosport area and the Southeast Texas Matagorda County (SETMAG). This system provides Mutual Aid from other industry members in the Brazosport and Matagorda County areas. Also, the Brazoria Volunteer Fire Department and West Brazos Emergency Medical Services would provide assistance in the event of an emergency. The EAAC conducts emergency drills quarterly each year, hosted by a facility with other member facilities participating.

VII.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Some new and/or planned upcoming projects (some on-going) or changes to continue to improve safety and environmental performance include the following:
Emergency Shutdown Valves on Critical Equipment Lines
Facility Siting and Spacing Analysis, Reviews and Initiatives
Atmospheric Relief Valve and Relief Header Analysis
Facility Security & Vulnerability Assessments 
Conducting Emergency Response and CAER Drills
Simulator Training Program for Operators
Alarm Management/Rationalization Projects
Safety Instrumented Systems upgrades and application
Machine Guarding Emphasis
Pump Seal Upgrade Projects
